facts.text: Appeal under Section 116A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 from judgment and order dated May 10, 1968 of Rajasthan High Court in Election Petition No. 8 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1515 of 1968. Appeal under S. I 16-A of the Representation, of the People- Act, 1951 from the judgment and order dated May- 10, 1968 of the Rajasthan High Court in Election Petition No. 8 of 1967.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court dismissed the Election Petition filed by the appellant against respondent Mohan Lal Sukhadia.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is against the judgment of the Rajasthan High Court dated 10 May, 1968, dismissing the Election Petition filed by the appellant against the respondent Mohan Lal Sukhadia.

facts.text: Election of respondent Mohan Lal Sukhadia to Rajasthan Legislative Assembly from Udaipur City Assembly Constituency was challenged.

anchor.surface_text: The election of respondent Mohan Lal Sukhadia to the Rajas- than Legislative Assembly from the Udaipur City Assembly Constituency was challenged.

facts.text: Appellant contested the election on Jan Sangh ticket.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytested the election on Jan Sangh ticket.

facts.text: Respondent Mohan Lal Sukhadia contested on Congress ticket and was Chief Minister of Rajasthan at the time of election.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companytested on Congress ticket. The respondent was the Chief Minister of Rajasthan at the time of the election.

facts.text: Polling took place on 15 February 1967.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of this appeal we are companycerned only with the respondent Mohan Lal Sukhadia. The polling took place on 15 February,1967.

facts.text: Result declared on 21 February 1967; respondent polled 24272 votes, petitioner 20841 votes, margin 3431 votes.

anchor.surface_text: The result was declared on 21 February, 1967. Therespondent polled 24272 votes. The petitioner obtained 20841votes. The respondent won by a margin of 3434 votes.

facts.text: After election, Congress Party reduced to minority; respondent Sukhadia tendered resignation as Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: After the election the Congress Party wasreduced to a minority. The respondent Sukhadia Who was theChief Minister tendered his resignation.

facts.text: President's Rule declared in Rajasthan on 13 March 1967, withdrawn on 26 April 1967 after 44 days.

anchor.surface_text: On 13 March, 1967, the Presidents Rule was declared in Rajasthan, which was withdrawn after a period of 44 days on 26 April, 1967.

facts.text: Election petition filed on 7 April 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the respondent Sukhadia again became the Chief Minister. The election petition was filed on 7 April, 1967.

facts.text: High Court allowed appellant to furnish particulars on 29 May 1967 and incorporate in amended petition by orders dated 3/5/6 July 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court ordered the petitioner to file a detailed reply giving full particulars in respect of each matter. On 29 May, 1967, the appellant furnished parti- culars. The High Court by orders dated 3/5/6 July, 1967 allowed the appellant to incorporate the said particulars in the amended petition

facts.text: Amended Election Petition filed on 19 July 1967.

anchor.surface_text: On 19 July, 1967, an amended Election Petition was filed incorporating the amendments allowed by the High Court.

facts.text: Issues framed on 14 August 1967; finally amended petition on 13 November 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter written statements were filed and the parties filed applications under Rule 12 of the Election Rules for production of the documents. Issues were framed on 14 August, 1967. The appellant filed a finally amended petition on 13 November, 1967.

facts.text: Appellant examined 30 witnesses, respondent Sukhadia examined 46 witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant examined 30 witnesses and the respondent Sukhadia examined 46 witnesses.

facts.text: High Court decided issues 3(a), 3(b), 4(a), 4(b) in favour of respondent and dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court decided all the issues in favour of the respondent Sukhadia and dismissed the Election Petition but left the respondent to bear his own companyt. In the present appeal we are companycerned only with issues Nos. 3  a  and 4  a .

facts.text: Allegations in paras 8-11 of petition concern corrupt practices of bribery and undue influence re: public works like covering Baluchistan Colony Nallah, road at Tekri, water-taps, pattas to Raigar Colony.

anchor.surface_text: As to issue No. 3 based on paragraphs 8, 9,.10 and 11 of the Election Petition, allegations of companyrupt practice of bribery and undue influence companycerned with the companystruction of certain works of general public utility to the inhabitants of Udaipur like the companyering of Baluchistan Colony Nallah, companystruction of road at Tekri, installation of water-taps in Udaipur City and the grant of Pattas to-the inhabitants of the Raigar Colony.

facts.text: Appellant made 74 allegations of corrupt practices; 55 given up at trial; pressed 3 in appeal: pattas Raigar Colony, roads Tekri, Nallah Baluchistan.

anchor.surface_text: In the petition the appellant made 74 allegations. At the trial 55 allegations were given up. In the present appeal the appellant pressed allegations first about Pattas in Raigar Colony secondly, about roads in Tekri thirdly, companyering of Nallah in Baluchistan

facts.text: Meeting at Raigar Colony on 5 February 1967 arranged by Girdhari Lal; respondent allegedly promised pattas at Re.1/- and asked for votes.

anchor.surface_text: Girdhari Lal, election agent of the respondent Sukhadia arranged a meeting on 5 February, 1967 at the Raigar Colony. About 100 persons gathered. The audience companysisted of Harijans and Raigars. ... The respondent Sukhadia said that he was managing Pattas of the land to be allotted to them for Re. 1/- each and he requested them to vote for him.

facts.text: Order No. 66/5077 dated 10 February 1967 issued by Director Social Welfare to grant pattas to Raigars at Re.1/- per patta.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Sukhadia by his undue influence as Chief Minister got issued an order No. 66/5077 dated 10 February, 1967, from the Director, Social Welfare De- partment, Jaipur to grant Pattas to Raigars of Thakker Bapa Colony for companystruction of houses at a numberinal price of Re. 1/for each patta.

facts.text: High Court held no proof that respondent made bargain for votes at Raigar Colony meeting on 5 Feb 1967; policy from 1959 (Ex A-99) and 1962 (Ex A-100).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that it had number been proved that the respondent Sukhadia made a bargain with the people of Raigar Colony on 5 February, 1967, that if they promised to vote for him he would arrange for the grant of Pattas to them at a numberinal charge of Re. 1/- each Patta.

facts.text: No meeting at Raigar Colony on 5 Feb 1967 as per respondent's tour programme (Sindhi Samaj 4pm etc.); oral evidence disbelieved.

anchor.surface_text: The oral evidence of Lakshmi Narain and Kalu Ram is unworthy of belief. The documentary evidence fortifies the oral evidence of respondent Sukhadia that there was numbermeeting of Raigars and Harijans at Udaipur on 5 February, 1967.

facts.text: Allegation of road construction at Tekri as corrupt practice; work planned 1965-66, agreements Feb-April 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly stated the appellants allegations were that the respondent Sukhadia ordered Public Works Department  P.W.D.  to companystruct a road at Tekri though it was a municipal area and P.W.D. had numberjurisdiction

facts.text: High Court held no evidence of bargain for votes at Tekri; road work longstanding, no irregularity.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that there was numberevidence that it was the respondent Sukhadia who got the work on Tekri road started by Chhail Behari Mathur. The High Court further held that there was numberevidence of bargain for voting at the election.

facts.text: Nallah covering in Baluchistan Colony scheme from Sep 1966; sanction Mar 1967 after President's Rule.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alleged in paragraph 8 of the amended petition that the respondent Sukhadia, his election agent, other agents and other persons with the companysent of the respondent Sukhadia misused his position as Chief Minister and ordered the Public Works Department to companystruct roads and Nallah inter alia at Ward No. 27 in Baluchistan Colony.

facts.text: No evidence respondent promised Nallah work for votes; longstanding grievance, urgency.

anchor.surface_text: It is impossible to impute any motive whatsoever to the respondent Sukhadia that he was guided by any companyrupt motive for any election bargaining.

facts.text: Allegation of 50 water taps installed 2-3 days before poll; High Court found no evidence respondent influenced.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant alleged that the respondent by exercising his influence as Chief Minister got 50 public water-taps installed in different localities of Udaipur City Constituency two or three days before the poll.

facts.text: Leaflet Ex.8-A alleged petitioner encroached govt land; High Court held not with consent of respondent or agent, not prejudicial.

anchor.surface_text: The last allegation on which the appellant relied as an ins- tance of companyrupt practice was Ex. 8, which was a leaflet. The leaflet companytained a statement The Vice-President of Jan Sangh Shri Bhanu Kumar Shastri took illegal possession of Government land

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeal, no corrupt practice proved.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we are of opinion that the appellant is number entitled to succeed. The appeal fails and is dismissed. Parties, will pay and bear their own companyts.

issues.text: Whether the respondent is entitled to challenge findings of fact by the High Court against him without preferring an appeal?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel on behalf of the appellant contended that it was not open to the respondent to challenge several findings of fact by the High Court against the respondent without preferring an appeal.

arguments.claim: Respondent Sukhadia committed corrupt practice of bribery by promising pattas at Re.1/- at Raigar Colony meeting on 5 February 1967 to induce votes.

anchor.surface_text: Girdhari Lal, election agent of the respondent Sukhadia arranged a meeting on 5 February, 1967 at the Raigar Colony. About 100 persons gathered. The audience companysisted of Harijans and Raigars. ... The respondent Sukhadia said that he was managing Pattas of the land to be allotted to them for Re. 1/- each and he requested them to vote for him.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not raised in pleadings; no scheme proved covering Tekri; road not 'improvement'.

holdings.text: The oral evidence of Lakshmi Narain and Kalu Ram is unworthy of belief. The documentary evidence fortifies the oral evidence of respondent Sukhadia that there was no meeting of Raigars and Harijans at Udaipur on 5 February, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The oral evidence of Lakshmi Narain and Kalu Ram is unworthy of belief. The documentary evidence fortifies the oral evidence of respondent Sukhadia that there was no meeting of Raigars and Harijans at Udaipur on 5 February, 1967.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Oral testimony unreliable due to inconsistencies and interest; contradicted by tour programme Ex A-116, police records, and absence of key witnesses; longstanding policy from 1959 negates inducement.

holdings.text: The High Court rightly rejected the oral evidence of bargain and characterised the evidence on behalf of the appellant as being wholly concocted and fabricated.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly rejected the oral evidence of bargain and characterised the evidence on behalf of the appellant as being wholly concocted and fabricated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof of promise or bargain for votes; Ex 271 and 44 implement 1959/1962 policy; demand from 1955; no new inducement near election.

holdings.text: There was no evidence that it was the respondent Sukhadia who got the work on Tekri road started by Chhail Behari Mathur. The High Court further held that there was no evidence of bargain for voting at the election. That finding is correct and we do not find any reason to take a contrary view.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that there was no evidence that it was the respondent Sukhadia who got the work on Tekri road started by Chhail Behari Mathur. The High Court further held that there was no evidence of bargain for voting at the election.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Work planned 1965-66 due to longstanding grievance; rules 330/351/369 permit piece-work without tenders; no irregularity; witnesses disbelieved.

holdings.text: We agree with the High Court that there was no corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that there was no corrupt practice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No sudden activity or favour; normal official duty; roller use on poll day not corrupt.

holdings.text: It is impossible to impute any motive whatsoever to the respondent Sukhadia that he was guided by any corrupt motive for any election bargaining.

anchor.surface_text: It is impossible to impute any motive whatsoever to the respondent Sukhadia that he was guided by any corrupt motive for any election bargaining.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme from Sep 1966; longstanding insanitary issue; urgency; sanction during President's Rule; ordinary official noting.

holdings.text: The High Court came to the conclusion that the documentary evidence on record did not warrant a finding that the respondent got the public hydrants installed by the exercise of his influence. We have not found any reason to hold that the High Court was in error.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court came to the conclusion that the documentary evidence on record did not warrant a finding that the respondent got the public hydrants installed by the exercise of his influence.

holdings.text: The High Court correctly held that neither the respondent nor his election agent, Girdhari Lal got the leaflet Ex. 8 printed or gave consent to its being printed and further that it could not be held that the respondent or his agent had knowledge of the distribution of the leaflet.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court correctly held that neither the respondent nor his election agent, Girdhari Lal got the leaflet Ex. 8 printed or gave consent to its being printed and further that it could not be held that the respondent or his agent had knowledge of the distribution of the leaflet.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Printed for District Congress/Bhuleshwar Mina; no allegation or proof of knowledge/consent by respondent/agent.

holdings.text: We do not see any reason to take a different view.

anchor.surface_text: We do not see any reason to take a different view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Oral evidence rejected; possible contact but no defamatory statement proved.

holdings.text: The provisions contained in Order 41, R. 22 of the Code of Civil Procedure are attracted by the words of section 116C of the Representation of the People Act with the result that the respondent may support the decision and judgment on any ground decided against him.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions contained in Order 41, R. 22 of the Code of Civil Procedure are attracted by the words of section 116C of the Representation of the People Act with the result that the respondent may support the decision and judgment on any ground decided against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S116C incorporates CPC procedure; cites Ramanbhai Patel and T.N. Angami; justice requires allowing support without cross-appeal.

holdings.text: Allegation of corrupt practice is a charge of criminal nature. The onus of proof of corrupt practice is on the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Allegation of corrupt practice is a charge of criminal nature. The onus of proof of corrupt practice is on the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict proof required as criminal charge; petitioner failed to discharge onus across all allegations.

holdings.text: Under section 123(1) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, bribery is said to be a gift, offer or promise by a candidate of any gratification to any person with the object directly or indirectly of inducing an elector to vote at an election.

anchor.surface_text: Under Section 123 1  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, bribery is mentioned as a corrupt practice and bribery is any gift offer promise by a candidate of any gratification

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof of gift/offer/promise with inducement object in any instance.

holdings.text: If everyone of his official acts done bonafide is to be construed against him and an ulterior motive is spelled out of them, the administration must necessarily come to a stand-still.

anchor.surface_text: First, the position of a Minister is difficult. It is obvious that he cannot to function when his election is due. He must of necessity attend to the grievances

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Ghasi Ram and Om Prabha; bona fide ministerial acts redress longstanding grievances not corrupt without proof of bargain; no abuse here.

holdings.text: For these reasons we are of opinion that the appellant is not entitled to succeed. The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we are of opinion that the appellant is not entitled to succeed. The appeal fails and is dismissed. Parties, will pay and bear their own costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No corrupt practices proved under s123(1),(2),(4); longstanding grievances redressed bona fide; no evidence of election bargains.

precedents.citation: Ramanbhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji Ors. 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Ramanbhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji Ors. 1 , negatived the contention that the respondent was not competent to challenge the correctness of a finding as he had not preferred an appeal and said We cannot lose sight of the fact that normally a party in whose favour the judgment appealed from has been given will not be granted special leave to appeal from it.

precedents.case_name: Ramanbhai Ashabhai Patel v. Dabhi Ajitkumar Fulsinji Ors.
precedents.cited_proposition: respondent may support the decision and judgment on any ground decided against him even without preferring an appeal
precedents.cited_holding: We cannot lose sight of the fact that normally a party in whose favour the judgment appealed from has been given will not be granted special leave to appeal from it. Considerations of justice, therefore require that this Court should in appropriate cases permit a party placed in such a position to support the judgment in his favour even upon grounds which were negatived in that judgment.

precedents.citation: T, N. Angami v. Smt. Ravalu Reno M. Shaiza Civil Appeal No. 1125 of 1970

anchor.surface_text: In the recent case in T, N. Angami v. Smt. Ravalu Reno M. Shaiza Civil Appeal No. 1125 of 1970 this Court in the judgment dated 21 January 1971 reiterated the views expressed in the case of Ramanbhai Ashabhai Patel supra .

precedents.case_name: T. N. Angami v. Smt. Ravalu Reno M. Shaiza
precedents.cited_proposition: reiterated the views that respondent can support judgment on grounds negatived without appeal

precedents.citation: Ghasi Ram v. Dal Singh Others 1

anchor.surface_text: In Ghasi Ram v. Dal Singh Others 1 and Om Prabha Jain v. Abhash Chand Anr. 2 , this Court considered acts of Ministers, who were candidates at elections in relation to using discretionary fund on the eve of the election.

precedents.case_name: Ghasi Ram v. Dal Singh Others
precedents.cited_proposition: acts of Ministers using discretionary fund on eve of election; position of Minister is difficult and normal functioning cannot be stopped; thin line between evil practice and corrupt practice

precedents.citation: Om Prabha Jain v. Abhash Chand Anr. 2

anchor.surface_text: In Ghasi Ram v. Dal Singh Others 1 and Om Prabha Jain v. Abhash Chand Anr. 2 , this Court considered acts of Ministers, who were candidates at elections in relation to using discretionary fund on the eve of the election. Two propositions were established.

precedents.case_name: Om Prabha Jain v. Abhash Chand Anr.
precedents.cited_proposition: acts of Ministers using discretionary fund on eve of election; position of Minister is difficult and normal functioning cannot be stopped; thin line between evil practice and corrupt practice
